ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned more advanced Chinese vocabulary and grammatical structures. I'm now more confident in my ability to follow along with Chinese-language films.  Gained experience with reading satirical short stories.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the strength is that this class is low stress and relatively easy but you still learn a lot. It could be improved by more opportunities to practice speaking and pronounciation.

Strengths: Most of the texts were very interesting, and the vocabulary in them seems useful. I enjoyed the small class format because it gave me a lot of chances to practice speaking. 
Weaknesses: Some of the texts and films seemed a little dated, and some of the vocabulary from these texts didn't seem totally modern. Also, having both an oral exam and a chapter test in two consecutive classes is too much, I think they should be spread out to separate weeks.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This is a good continuation of Chinese. The class is easy, grading is not to harsh, but you will still learn a lot.

CHNS 159 (Advanced Chinese IV through Films and Stories) with Dr. Zhang Yongtao () has been the single best Chinese language class Ive ever taken. I was fortunate enough to take CHNS 158 (Advanced Chinese III through Films and Stories) with Dr. Zhang during this past Fall 22 semester and loved it so much that I decided to continue this semester with CHNS 159 (important to note that the courses stand separately and do not have to be taken consecutively).

Zhang Laoshi is a rockstar who has created an engaging curriculum developed around carefully curated contemporary films and stories spanning multiple genres, geographies and time. If you think you would enjoy watching, dissecting and discussing major and important Chinese language contemporary and popular films, this is the class for you! 

Zhang Laoshi has thoughtfully architected a classroom environment that is light, collaborative and fun. Like most L5 courses, there is significant daily work including weekly quizzes, homework, presentations as well as individual and group projects - all of which require time and energy; but the workload never feels onerous and perhaps most importantly, relates directly and grows your ability to engage with the films and stories. Throughout the entire course, Dr. Zhang was always encouraging, supportive and incredibly responsive    an engaged teacher who works tirelessly to provide actionable and helpful feedback and who cares deeply about his students experiences and language progress. At the risk of sounding obsequious, Dr. Zhang is an amazing resource for Yale  he taught at Princeton before coming to New Haven and prior to that, he is the person who helped architect and run the renowned Princeton in Beijing (PIB) program for many years. If you are willing to put in the work, I could not recommend Dr. Zhang and this course (and entire sequence  CHNS 158 and 159) more highly.
Yes. This class is so fun.
